content.title: STEMI Diagnostic Criteria
content.summary: ST-elevation myocardial infarction diagnostic ECG criteria and STEMI equivalents
key_points: ≥1mm ST elevation in 2 contiguous leads (most leads)
V2-V3: ≥2mm in men ≥40y, ≥2.5mm in men <40y, ≥1.5mm in women
New LBBB with ischemic symptoms is STEMI equivalent
Posterior MI: ST depression V1-V3 with tall R waves
De Winter T-waves are STEMI equivalent

statement.text: ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is diagnosed by new ST-elevation at the J-point in 2 or more contiguous leads with cut-points: ≥1mm in all leads except V2-V3 where ≥2mm in men ≥40 years, ≥2.5mm in men <40 years, or ≥1.5mm in women is required. STEMI equivalents include new LBBB with ischemic symptoms, de Winter T-waves, posterior MI pattern, and Wellens' syndrome.
statement.formal: STEMI = ST↑ ≥1mm in 2 contiguous leads (V2-V3: ≥2/2.5/1.5mm by sex/age) OR STEMI equivalent (new LBBB, de Winter, posterior MI)

explanation.intuition: STEMI represents complete coronary artery occlusion causing transmural ischemia of the full wall thickness. This manifests as ST-segment elevation because the entire wall from endocardium to epicardium is affected, creating a current of injury visible on surface ECG.
explanation.key_insight: STEMI requires emergent reperfusion therapy (PCI or fibrinolysis). Every minute of delay increases mortality - 'time is muscle'. Door-to-balloon time should be <90 minutes; door-to-needle time for fibrinolysis should be <30 minutes.
explanation.technical_details: ST elevation reflects subepicardial injury current. The J-point (junction of QRS and ST segment) is the measurement point. Contiguous leads share anatomic proximity: V1-V2 (septum), V3-V4 (anterior), V5-V6 (lateral), II-III-aVF (inferior), I-aVL (high lateral).

definitions_glossary.STEMI: ST-elevation myocardial infarction - complete coronary occlusion with transmural ischemia
definitions_glossary.J_point: Junction between QRS complex and ST segment where ST elevation is measured
definitions_glossary.contiguous_leads: ECG leads representing anatomically adjacent myocardial regions
definitions_glossary.transmural_ischemia: Ischemia affecting full thickness of myocardial wall
definitions_glossary.LBBB: Left bundle branch block - conduction delay in left bundle causing QRS widening
definitions_glossary.de_Winter_T_waves: Upsloping ST depression at J-point with tall symmetric T-waves - LAD occlusion equivalent
definitions_glossary.posterior_MI: Infarction of posterior wall, seen as reciprocal changes in anterior leads
definitions_glossary.Wellens_syndrome: Deep symmetric T-wave inversions in V2-V3 indicating proximal LAD stenosis
definitions_glossary.door_to_balloon_time: Time from hospital arrival to first balloon inflation in primary PCI
definitions_glossary.door_to_needle_time: Time from hospital arrival to fibrinolytic administration
definitions_glossary.current_of_injury: Electrical potential difference between normal and ischemic myocardium
definitions_glossary.reciprocal_changes: ST depression in leads opposite to ST elevation, indicating true STEMI
definitions_glossary.hyperacute_T_waves: Tall peaked T-waves occurring early in acute MI before ST elevation develops

pathophysiology.mechanism: Complete occlusion of epicardial coronary artery (usually by thrombus on ruptured plaque) causes transmural ischemia. Subendocardial layers die first, with wavefront extending to epicardium over time. ST elevation reflects the current of injury from ischemic epicardium.
ECG_evolution: Acute phase (minutes-hours): ST elevation with upward concavity → straight → convex
Evolving phase (hours-days): T-wave inversion, Q-wave development
Chronic phase (weeks-months): Q-waves persist, ST normalizes, T-waves may normalize or remain inverted

coronary_territory_correlation.posterior: V7-V9 elevation; reciprocal V1-V3 depression with tall R

standard_cutoffs.most_leads: ≥1mm ST elevation at J-point in ≥2 contiguous leads

STEMI_equivalents: New LBBB (or presumed new) with ischemic symptoms
De Winter T-waves (1-3mm upsloping ST depression at J-point + tall symmetric T-waves in V1-V6)
Posterior MI (ST depression V1-V3, tall R waves, confirm with V7-V9)
Sgarbossa criteria positive in setting of LBBB or paced rhythm
Wellens' syndrome (Type A: biphasic T in V2-V3; Type B: deep symmetric T-wave inversions V2-V3)

original: Concordant ST elevation ≥1mm in leads with positive QRS (5 points)
Concordant ST depression ≥1mm in V1-V3 (3 points)
Discordant ST elevation ≥5mm in leads with negative QRS (2 points)
Sgarbossa_criteria.modified_Smith: Discordant ST elevation / S-wave amplitude ratio ≥0.25 replaces 5mm rule

immediate_management: Nitroglycerin (if not hypotensive, no RV infarct, no PDE5 inhibitor use)
Morphine (if pain not controlled by nitrates)

primary_PCI.indication: Preferred strategy for all STEMI patients
primary_PCI.time_goal: Door-to-balloon <90 minutes; first medical contact to device <120 minutes
primary_PCI.advantages: Higher patency rates, lower reocclusion, better outcomes than fibrinolysis

fibrinolysis.indication: If PCI not available within 120 minutes of first medical contact
fibrinolysis.contraindications: Prior ICH, known cerebral vascular lesion, active bleeding, recent major surgery

rescue_PCI.indication: Failed fibrinolysis (<50% ST resolution at 60-90 minutes)

definition.@value: Myocardial infarction with ST-segment elevation on ECG indicating complete coronary artery occlusion requiring emergent reperfusion therapy

skos.scopeNote: Includes STEMI equivalents: new LBBB, de Winter T-waves, posterior MI, Wellens' syndrome
skos.example: 62-year-old male with crushing chest pain, 3mm ST elevation in V1-V4, reciprocal ST depression in II/III/aVF - anterior STEMI from LAD occlusion

medicalCode.description: Acute ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (disorder)
ST elevation (STEMI) myocardial infarction of anterior wall
ST elevation (STEMI) myocardial infarction of inferior wall
ST elevation (STEMI) myocardial infarction of other sites

learning_objectives: Apply ST elevation criteria including sex/age-specific V2-V3 cutoffs
Identify STEMI equivalents (new LBBB, de Winter, posterior MI, Wellens')
Correlate ECG findings with coronary artery territories
Apply Sgarbossa criteria in LBBB and paced rhythms
Determine appropriate reperfusion strategy based on time and resources
clinical_pearls: Always get right-sided leads (V3R-V4R) in inferior STEMI to assess RV involvement
De Winter T-waves = STEMI equivalent even without ST elevation - needs emergent PCI
Posterior MI has ST depression V1-V3 with tall R (mirror image of posterior ST elevation)
Modified Smith-Sgarbossa (≥0.25 ratio) outperforms original criteria for LBBB
Hyperacute T-waves precede ST elevation - treat as STEMI if clinical suspicion high

board_yield.usmle_step1: High - ECG interpretation, coronary artery anatomy
board_yield.usmle_step2: Very High - STEMI recognition, treatment algorithm, time goals

common_misconceptions: LBBB always obscures MI diagnosis (false - use Sgarbossa criteria)
Normal ST segments exclude acute MI (false - de Winter, posterior MI, hyperacute)
All ST elevation is STEMI (false - pericarditis, early repolarization, LVH, Brugada)

skos:related.skos:note: Alternative ACS presentation without ST elevation

sources.source: O'Gara PT, et al. 2013 ACCF/AHA Guideline for STEMI Management. Circulation 2013;127:e362-e425
Thygesen K, et al. Fourth Universal Definition of Myocardial Infarction. Circulation 2018;138:e618-e651
de Winter RJ, et al. A new ECG sign of proximal LAD occlusion. N Engl J Med 2008;359:2071-3
